High COVID-19 mortality in these groups was largely due to high risk of infection.

New analysis shows lower #COVID19 survival rates in Bangladeshi, Pakistani, Chinese, & Indian ethnic groups remained after adjusting for comorbidities.

It‚Äôs likely timing of tests and treatment & socioeconomic factors contributed to poorer outcomes.

This morning we heard from Sir Simon Stevens @NHSEngland as part of our joint #COVID19LessonsLearnt inquiry with @CommonsSTC.

This is his answer for what a new '1948 moment' for health and social care would look like.

Watch the session back: https://t.co/ocxNSzFAU7 https://t.co/nfsJIKRrA1

Our session with Sir Simon Stevens on #COVID19LessonsLearnt has now ended, with thanks to him for his time and our best wishes to the whole @NHSEngland team.

You can watch the session back here: https://t.co/MkByiHLsg5 https://t.co/SmIiM8OAbv

Sir Simon Stevens praises the role of the armed forces in the supporting the NHS but highlights the speed with which the NHS responded. He says one of the big #COVID19LessonsLearnt is that resilience in public services requires buffer and buffer can look wasteful - until it isn't

Asked about NHS staff planning, Sir Simon says @NHSEngland is lucky to have a medium-term outlook of its funding but investment in staffing and capital has been more short-term. He says anything that can bring predictability in these areas would be welcome #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Sir Simon says that he and others are hopeful that in the next 6-18 months not only vaccines but also other therapies will help the NHS to manage coronavirus more effectively and therefore allow normal services to recover #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Sir Simon Stevens says there is "deep concern" about vaccine hesitancy in certain populations and says the NHS is working to overcome access issues, longstanding mistrust and systematic efforts to lie about the vaccine to minority ethnic populations #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Tomorrow at 11am we'll be hearing from Sir Simon Stevens @NHSEngland as part of our #COVID19LessonsLearnt inquiry with @CommonsSTC.

You can watch the lesson live here: https://t.co/MkByiHLsg5 https://t.co/Nbl55Tog6n

On Tuesday 26 January we'll hear from Sir Simon Stevens @NHSEngland in our #COVID19LessonsLearnt inquiry with @CommonsSTC. 

Sir Simon will be talking to us about lessons learnt from the pandemic so far and the current situation in the NHS.

Watch live: https://t.co/MkByiHLsg5 https://t.co/YPRJusXmfW

Our session on #coronavirus with the Secretary of State has now finished.

You can watch the session back here: https://t.co/qsnnxmdamK

üìó Keep an eye out for the transcript.

On staff required to deliver #coronavirus vaccines, @MattHancock says training requirements such as fire safety have been removed, but acknowledges that significant pressure on hospitals due to high numbers of Covid-19 cases will limit the workforce

Asked why there is not a full dashboard of vaccine data available, @MattHancock says that as the vaccination programme grows, more and more information will be put out into the public domain with the aim of increasing trust #coronavirus

Asked why community pharmacists are not delivering #coronavirus vaccines, @MattHancock says the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine wasn't appropriate for pharmacy delivery due to the cold chain needed but says delivery in pharmacy settings is increasing for the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine
However, he adds that the number of people in hospital with #coronavirus will likely fall more slowly as younger people tend to stay longer in hospital
.@MattHancock says he is as confident as he can be that the number of deaths from #coronavirus will fall relative to the number of cases once everyone in cohorts 1 to 4 has been vaccinated

.@MattHancock says it is for @MHRAgovuk to decide whether or not social care workers could be allowed to conduct lateral flow tests for #coronavirus at home before coming into work, but says they are looking at it

.@MattHancock is asked why the UK has not yet introduced border measures beyond quarantine to control #coronavirus - he says the UK has a targeted approach to border measures e.g. only British Nationals are allowed to travel from the UK from South Africa

Today's session with the Secretary of State @MattHancock will now begin at the slightly later time of 3pm.

We'll be questioning him about the latest #coronavirus developments.

1/ In October we launched our joint inquiry with @CommonsSTC on the lessons learnt from covid-19. Here‚Äôs a recap of some of the key things we‚Äôve heard so far. #COVID19LessonsLearnt @Jeremy_Hunt

Asked about the logistics of mass testing including identity assurance, @MattHancock agrees that this is very important and says that this is currently being tested in the trials in Liverpool, and will then be rolled out to NHS and social care staff #COVID19LessonsLearnt

One of the lessons we need to look really hard at is the national risk assessment process and the extent to which it is interrogated and challenged, says @AlexGAThomas. It's clear that references to novel coronaviruses in risk register were too dismissive #COVID19LessonsLearnt

On Christmas, @devisridhar says the issue is that people want to hear reassuring messages, but the virus doesn't care that it's Christmas - mixing indoors, with alcohol, and with elderly relatives, is very risky #COVID19LessonsLearnt

üì∫Watch the session back: https://t.co/fCYi98Xxhi

üìóAnd look out for the transcript. https://t.co/BXrntlbwfd

@didoharding says her and her team is still focussed on covid, but agrees that we have built a very large diagnostic industry and says it's important to make sure the country benefits from that going beyond covid, including treating other diseases #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@didoharding says she thinks that local and national contact tracing is not an either/or choice but that both parts of the system are important and should both be funded effectively #COVID19LessonsLearnt

The final panel of this morning's #COVID19LessonsLearnt session is now beginning.

We are questioning @didoharding and @SMHopkins from NHS Test and Trace.

Keep watching and following live tweets: https://t.co/fCYi98Xxhi

üëá

He says running a PCR test is not magic - and in Germany there was never a notion that one centralised lab would claim to be the only one to know how to run COVID tests. He adds that there were financial incentives for smaller labs to run COVID tests #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@JoMartin_path says NHS pathology labs process 1.1bn tests per year so they were well set up for high volume testing. She says the decision to set up independent labs, where data didn't flow well into the NHS and public health, is something we've learnt from #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about the scaling up of lab capacity through smaller labs, @JoMartin_path says smaller NHS labs were desperate to ramp up testing in the early part of the pandemic but faced significant constraints, especially in the supply of testing materials #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@BWDDPH suggests people may be underreporting contacts to national Test and Trace to protect them from self-isolating. He calls for a stronger system of support & welcomes the ¬£500 payment for people self-isolating, which is being highly utilised in his area #COVID19LessonsLearnt

He adds that there has been a shift from the national to local but it's been too slow, and if the Government had moved more quickly over the summer to shift contact tracing locally, we'd be in a better place now #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Our next #COVID19LessonsLearnt session with @CommonsSTC is starting soon. We'll be discussing test, trace and isolate.

The importance of regular coronavirus testing in social care was a key topic in our first #COVID19LessonsLearnt session with @CommonsSTC today.

Here's what @KathyRobertsMH said about the current effectiveness of testing in social care.

Watch the session: https://t.co/pfE4AN2aNv https://t.co/PKSh42Tscf

The first evidence session for our joint inquiry with @CommonsSTC into #COVID19LessonsLearnt has now ended.

Thank you to all our witnesses and viewers. 

üíª Watch again: https://t.co/f5LugmbWBv

üìÉ Look out for the transcript https://t.co/0d2H0bAey3

On testing, @JaneMCummings says over 15,400 care homes are currently taking part in regular testing, but says there are some issues with increasing turnaround times - but that median times for results to be returned is coming down again #COVID19LessonsLearnt
@Helen_Whately says she is committed to long-term reform of social care but cannot give any further information on the timeline for proposals to be published #COVID19LessonsLearnt

On rapid discharge to social care, @Helen_Whately says in every area facilities are now being accredited by the CQC as having the gold standard for infection control, so patients can be discharged to specific locations safely. #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about agency workers working across different care homes, @Helen_Whately says the Government has now moved to mandating agency workers to work in only one setting, support by infection control funding #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@mancunianmedic agrees there were underlying structural problems with the funding of social care before the pandemic - he says now at least we have them in the spotlight. He'd like to see a cross-party solution that does not exclude informal carers #COVID19LessonsLearnt

He says a strong social care voice at national planning discussions may have stopped some of these problems happening - protect the NHS essentially meant 'protect acute hospitals' #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@mancunianmedic says during the beginning of the pandemic there wasn't enough testing in all settings, there wasn't enough PPE, particularly in social care, and the health sector did not fully appreciate the difficulty of isolation control within care homes. #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@drjanetownson says social care is treated like a Victorian child, thrown scraps under the table from the NHS - she says we still have a long way to go before social care workers are seen as an integral part of the system #COVID19LessonsLearnt

On testing, @KathyRobertsMH also says turnaround times are not as good as they need to be: in care homes, results are generally coming back in 2-4 days, with a lot of regional variation #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@KathyRobertsMH says the testimony of Philip, Helen and Theresa shows the stark reality of the impact of the pandemic on individuals, families and providers - and the lack of parity between the NHS and social care #COVID19LessonsLearnt

We are now moving onto our second panel of witnesses - @drjanetownson, @KathyRoberts and @mancunianmedic for our joint inquiry with @CommonsSTC on #COVID19LessonsLearnt 

üì∫Watch live here: https://t.co/f5LugmbWBv

Follow live tweetsüëá

Theresa says that testing has now improved and her home is now getting weekly testing, but the turnaround times are not good enough - one member of staff had to wait 9 days for a test result #COVID19LessonsLearnt

She says she definitely felt pressured to admit residents without knowing their COVID status. At the beginning, Testing was non-existent, she says - care homes were not a priority for the tests that were available #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Theresa Steed, a care home manager, says the biggest impact on care homes during the first wave of the pandemic was hospitals being asked to empty their beds - she says there was not enough information on whether patients were COVID-positive or not #COVID19LessonsLearnt
She adds that clearer guidance would have helped her as a carer - she was getting contradictory information about her daughter's risk from coronavirus #COVID19LessonsLearnt
Asked what support could have helped her, Helen says that mental health support could have been quicker - it took 3 months to get Maja the help she needed #COVID19LessonsLearnt

He tells us he feels like care homes were sidelined during the beginning of the pandemic and should have been more of a focus. He says there was a lack of liaison between the NHS and social care, which is an ongoing problem #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about the proposed #NHS Bill, @ChrisCEOHopson argues that we probably don't have the national architecture right--as we have seen with testing. We need to be careful about having management and accountability too far away from frontline care, he says.

@ChrisCEOHopson says at the moment Trusts cannot guarantee sufficient reliable and consistent access to tests for #NHS staff in a timely way. There are still significant problems with laboratory capacity and access to reagents and chemicals.

We are already starting to see significant increases in #mentalhealth demand, in particular among those hit by the economic and social consequences of lockdown, says @ChrisCEOHopson. Too little of the extra funding promised has yet reached the front line.

There is a particular challenge for #mentalhealth  services, says @RichardDMurray1 , because they started from a lower point than many physical health services. We need to build up MH services in the same way as was done with other services pre-#Covid

It is going to be very difficult to go back to what we had in A+E before the #COVID crisis, warns @nedwards_1. We haven't got the testing or #PPE in place to restart elective care as fast as we might like. We are very likely to see waiting lists of 8 million by late autumn.

Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy Chief Medical Officer, is unable to give us an answer as to how many tests are needed. She explains that this depends on a variety of changing factors such as local circumstances, but the 100,000 puts us in a very good place #Coronavirus
@uksciencechief  continues: The plan now is to get the number of new cases back down to a manageable number as part of a system that can pick up small local outbreaks early. #coronavirus

He says: very young children tend to have less contact outside their own households compared to older children so they may be less likely to promote onward transmission between households #coronavirus

Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy Chief Medical Officer, tells us that for many elderly people in care homes there appears to be a different presentation of the disease, which has made its management more difficult #COVID„Éº19 https://t.co/L2ds9Ir8gp

@uksciencechief says it is very hard to give an overall estimate of 'R' (rate of infection) in care homes as they are spread around the country but bringing this under control, as well as transmission in hospitals, is critical to the overall control of the epidemic #COVID„Éº19

The Lord Speaker oversees proceedings in the #HouseofLords chamber and plays a key role in the Lords Administration. He also acts as an ambassador for the House in the UK and abroad, explaining and promoting its work as the second chamber of @UKParliament.

Lord McFall is Senior Deputy Speaker. He starts work as Lord Speaker on 1 May. He served as MP for Dumbarton and then West Dunbartonshire, working as a whip, in Northern Ireland Office government positions and as @CommonsTreasury Chair before becoming a #HouseofLords member.

In June 2020, as a response to the Coronavirus pandemic, the #HouseofLords had to find new ways to operate away from the #PalaceofWestminster. As a result, hybrid proceedings and remote voting were introduced. Both were a first for the House. https://t.co/ZdoAjr3Wfi

In 1999, after much debate of a #HouseofLords reform, the House of Lords Act came into force. The Act set out to make the membership of the House more diplomatic and representative of the British public. See more https://t.co/iH13vOuwg4 https://t.co/iUQATIcxs5

In recent months the #HouseofLords has adapted its ways of working in response to COVID-19, with the move to hybrid proceedings and online voting, enabling members to examine and shape legislation in person or remotely. See more: https://t.co/DE3OwiGRLk https://t.co/USZQJMbiCm
